conclusion: Determine the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for particles A and B during their deceleration phases.
For particle A, the deceleration phase is from t = t0 to t = 3t0.
For particle B, the deceleration phase is from t = 5t0 to t = 6t0.
For particle A, initial velocity v_A = 2v0.
For particle A, final velocity v_A = 0.
For particle A, time t_A = 3t0 - t0 = 2t0.
The magnitude of the acceleration for particle A is |a_A| = v0/t0.
For particle B, initial velocity v_B = v0.
For particle B, final velocity v_B = 0.
For particle B, time t_B = 6t0 - 5t0 = t0.
For particle B, acceleration a_B = (0 - v0) / t0 = -v0/t0.
The magnitude of the acceleration for particle B is |a_B| = v0/t0.
The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations is |a_A| / |a_B| = (v0/t0) / (v0/t0) = 1.
The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for A and B during their deceleration phases is 1.
